{\\\\n type: \\\\\\\"proposal/like\\\\\\\",\\\\n item,\\\\n proposal: proposalId,\\\\n widgetAccountId: REPL_INFRASTRUCTURE_COMMITTEE,\\\\n }\\\\n : {\\\\n type: \\\\\\\"rfp/like\\\\\\\",\\\\n item,\\\\n rfp: rfpId,\\\\n widgetAccountId: REPL_INFRASTRUCTURE_COMMITTEE,\\\\n },\\\\n };\\\\n }\\\\n });\\\\n if (notifyData.length > 0) {\\\\n data.index.notify = notifyData;\\\\n }\\\\n }\\\\n Social.set(data, {\\\\n onCommit: () => State.update({ loading: false, hasLike: !hasLike }),\\\\n onCancel: () =>\\\\n State.update({\\\\n loading: false,\\\\n hasLikeOptimistic: !state.hasLikeOptimistic,\\\\n }),\\\\n });\\\\n};\\\\n\\\\nconst title = hasLike ? \\\\n \\\\n Log in to comment\\\\n \\\\n \\\\n );\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nfunction extractMentions(text) {\\\\n const mentionRegex =\\\\n /@((?:(?:[a-z\\\\\\\\d]+[-_])*[a-z\\\\\\\\d]+\\\\\\\\.)*(?:[a-z\\\\\\\\d]+[-_])*[a-z\\\\\\\\d]+)/gi;\\\\n mentionRegex.lastIndex = 0;\\\\n const accountIds = new Set();\\\\n for (const match of text.matchAll(mentionRegex)) {\\\\n if (\\\\n !/[\\\\\\\\w`]/.test(match.input.charAt(match.index - 1)) &&\\\\n !/[/\\\\\\\\w`]/.test(match.input.charAt(match.index + match[0].length)) &&\\\\n match[1].length >= 2 &&\\\\n match[1].length <= 64\\\\n ) {\\\\n accountIds.add(match[1].toLowerCase());\\\\n }\\\\n }\\\\n return [...accountIds];\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nfunction extractTagNotifications(text, item) {\\\\n return extractMentions(text || \\\\\\\"\\\\\\\")\\\\n .filter((accountId) => accountId !== context.accountId)\\\\n .map((accountId) => ({\\\\n key: accountId,\\\\n value: {\\\\n type: \\\\\\\"mention\\\\\\\",\\\\n item,\\\\n },\\\\n }));\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nfunction composeData() {\\\\n setTxnCreated(true);\\\\n const data = {\\\\n post: {\\\\n comment: JSON.stringify({\\\\n type: \\\\\\\"md\\\\\\\",\\\\n text: comment,\\\\n item,\\\\n }),\\\\n },\\\\n index: {\\\\n comment: JSON.stringify({\\\\n key: item,\\\\n value: {\\\\n type: \\\\\\\"md\\\\\\\",\\\\n },\\\\n }),\\\\n },\\\\n };\\\\n\\\\n const notifications = extractTagNotifications(comment, {\\\\n type: \\\\\\\"social\\\\\\\",\\\\n path: `${accountId}/post/comment`,\\\\n });\\\\n\\\\n if (notifyAccountIds.length > 0) {\\\\n notifyAccountIds.map((account) => {\\\\n if (account !== context.accountId) {\\\\n notifications.push({\\\\n key: account,\\\\n value: proposalId\\\\n ? {\\\\n type: \\\\\\\"proposal/reply\\\\\\\",\\\\n item,\\\\n proposal: proposalId,\\\\n widgetAccountId: REPL_INFRASTRUCTURE_COMMITTEE,\\\\n }\\\\n : {\\\\n type: \\\\\\\"rfp/reply\\\\\\\",\\\\n item,\\\\n rfp: rfpId,\\\\n widgetAccountId: REPL_INFRASTRUCTURE_COMMITTEE,\\\\n },\\\\n });\\\\n }\\\\n });\\\\n }\\\\n\\\\n if (notifications.length) {\\\\n data.index.notify = JSON.stringify(\\\\n notifications.length > 1 ? notifications : notifications[0]\\\\n );\\\\n }\\\\n\\\\n Social.set(data, {\\\\n force: true,\\\\n onCommit: () => {\\\\n setCommentToast(true);\\\\n setComment(\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\");\\\\n setHandler(\\\\\\\"refreshEditor\\\\\\\");\\\\n setTxnCreated(false);\\\\n },\\\\n onCancel: () => {\\\\n setTxnCreated(false);\\\\n },\\\\n });\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nuseEffect(() => {\\\\n if (props.transactionHashes && comment) {\\\\n setComment(\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\");\\\\n }\\\\n}, [props.transactionHashes]);\\\\n\\\\nconst LoadingButtonSpinner = (\\\\n \\\\n);\\\\n\\\\nconst Compose = useMemo(() => {\\\\n return (\\\\n \\\\n );\\\\n}, [draftComment, handler]);\\\\n\\\\nreturn (\\\\n

{"body": {"name": "[Spilka] BOS UI for DAO creation and configuration", "summary": "We identified three principal gaps in current Sputnik-DAO UI capabilities\\\\n- DAO Management\\\\n- Discussions\\\\n- Reporting flow\\\\nIn this proposal, we consider implementing a BOS UI that focuses on the creation of DAO (wizard) and configuration (groups, legislative routines, thresholds). The goal is to lower the entry barrier for DAO enthusiasts who are not experienced developers.\\\\n\\\\nThis proposal complements [RFP] NEAR MultiSig Treasury with a clear focus on DAO creation and management", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "REVIEW", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "description": "## Organization\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\u{2019}s contact information\\\\nAlex Botezatu - Team Lead\\\\nEmail: botezatualex@gmail.com\\\\nTelegram: @botezatu\\\\nMobile: +380673753025\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the whole team\\\\n8 people.\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the engineering team\\\\n6 people - Product, Senior protocol engineer, 2 front-end engineers,UI/UX designer, QA engineer.\\\\n\\\\n### Team location\\\\nUkraine, Portugal.\\\\n\\\\n### Team background and bios\\\\n**Dan Polyakov, Product Lead**\\\\nHas been leading Product design teams for numerous crypto and fintech projects.\\\\nBitfury, KPMG, Golden Gate, NDC.\\\\n**Alex Botezatu, Ops Lead**\\\\nMore than 10 years of experience in building and managing R&D teams in web3.\\\\nBitfury, Aurora, NDC.\\\\n**Artur-Yurii Korchynskyi, Tech Lead**\\\\nInterchain Infrastructure Protocol: Programmable Layer 0 \\\\u{2022} ZK-Rollup \\\\u{2022} Advanced Liquidity Routing.\\\\n**Gleb Palienko, Project Manager**\\\\nHas been leading teams in web3 with project/product management and business development.\\\\nBitfury, P2P Validator, Boosty labs, Calimero.\\\\n**Andrii Saichuk, Front-End Engineer**\\\\nProficient Full Stack Web3 with over 10 years of experience in designing, developing, and maintaining complex web applications. Specializing in React.js for front-end development and proficient in NEAR. Owner of ZomLand and other Web3 dApps. Worked on NDC and contributed to open-source apps\\\\n**Andrii Furmanets, Front-End Engineer**\\\\nSpecialized in creating and deploying fintech and web3 applications. Recent work was focused on the NEAR blockchain and the Blockchain Operating System (BOS), where he has developed secure, scalable, and user-friendly decentralized applications.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Any affiliations with other NEAR ecosystem partners?\\\\nPart of the team (Dan, Alex B, Artur, Andrii S, Andrii F) worked on developing applications under the umbrella of NDC.\\\\nGleb worked in Calimero.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n## Professional Experience\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Examples of relevant experience with NEAR blockchain\\\\nDeveloped a voting solution for the stake-weighted voting. Developed applications for proposals and reports on funded initiatives on BOS.\\\\n\\\\n### Non-technical capabilities\\\\nAll non-engineer members of the group have been crypto native people since 2016.\\\\n\\\\nDan with his experience brings his ability to dive into the roots of every problem in Web3 resulting in the product vision and development lifecycle management.\\\\nAlex brings his management skills and ability to create, maintain, and manage highly qualified teams in the Web3 space.\\\\nGleb brings an outstanding combination of product/project management and business development skills that become the essence of the long-term strategy.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### In-House Resources\\\\n\\\\n- **Design, UX/UI** - we have an In-House UX/UI designer.\\\\n\\\\n- **Project management** - we have In-House project management capabilities.\\\\n\\\\n- **Customer support** - T3 engineering support. The management team can route support requests.\\\\n\\\\n- **BD / Marketing** - BD listed in non-technical capabilities.\\\\n\\\\n### Portfolio of relevant work\\\\n- https://github.com/near-ndc/voting-v2  - voting solution.\\\\n- https://github.com/near-ndc/ndc-widgets - BOS application for reports and proposals.\\\\n- https://github.com/ggxchain - Interchain infrastructure protocol.\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\n\\\\n### The primary approach and solution of the proposal.\\\\n\\\\n#### Project management approach\\\\n\\\\nWe utilize vertical slicing. Vertical slicing in agile breakdown refers to the practice of dividing work into thin, end-to-end slices that cut through all layers of the system to deliver a complete, functional piece of user value. Each vertical slice represents a small, independent feature or a user story that can be implemented, tested, and delivered to users.\\\\nHere are the key points about vertical slicing:\\\\n- Each vertical slice encompasses all necessary components (e.g., user interface, business logic, database interactions) to deliver a fully functional feature.\\\\n- The primary goal is to deliver tangible user value with each increment. This approach ensures that every slice results in a usable piece of software.\\\\n- Vertical slicing aligns with agile principles of incremental and iterative development, enabling us to deliver small, manageable pieces of functionality frequently.\\\\n- Vertical slicing encourages collaboration among team members with different expertise (e.g., frontend, backend, QA) to ensure that each slice is fully functional and integrated.\\\\n- By delivering complete features frequently, we can gather user feedback early and often, allowing for quicker adjustments and improvements.\\\\n- Since each vertical slice is a self-contained feature, integration issues are minimized compared to horizontal slicing, where different components must be integrated later.\\\\n\\\\nWe utilize an Agile approach with standard ceremonies (stand-up, grooming, refinement, review, retro). We will have 2-weeks sprints and we welcome Committee representatives to participate in our backlog management routines or review if needed. We aim to deliver tangible value each sprint and a practical piece of the end-to-end journey for each milestone.\\\\n\\\\nWe use Figma for the design. Reference for the style that will be used can be found [here](https://www.figma.com/design/Gaa51AGWBRTyKXF6TE2sjY/Astra%2B%2B-(Mobile)?node-id=0-1&t=CJlkI50FetgIrHtV-0).\\\\n\\\\n#### Solution overview\\\\nThe solution has four architectural components:\\\\n- Stable Sputnik DAO contract\\\\n- DAO contract created through the Sputnik DAO contract (%dao_name%.sputnik\\\\u{2026})\\\\n- BOS UI\\\\n- Open-source js backend\\\\n\\\\nBOS UI features:\\\\n- **[BOS-1]** Mobile first with adaptive design for the desktop\\\\n- **[BOS-2]** Wizard to create/disable DAO (new UX and implementation). Default user flow will create a DAO with 2 pre-set groups - Council and Members.\\\\n- **[BOS-3]** UI to define legislative proposal routines. \\\\n  - **[BOS-3.1]** Add/delete member to the group\\\\n  - **[BOS-3.2]** Add/delete group\\\\n  - **[BOS-3.3]** Add/delete funding threshold (e.g. if we have 10000, 50000, 10000 we can configure different quorum requirements for intervals 0-10000, 10000-50000, 50000-100000). A quorum requirement can be set for each group and using \\\\u{201c}AND\\\\u{201d} or \\\\u{201c}OR\\\\u{201d} logical operations e.g. need 60% councils AND 50% members.\\\\n  - **[BOS-3.4]** Add quorum requirement per group/funding threshold\\\\n- **[BOS-4]** UI to browse through legislative proposals with full data available on who voted how on each proposal\\\\n- **[BOS-5]** UI to vote on proposals\\\\n\\\\nDAO contract features:\\\\n- **[DAO-1]** Support data structures for DAO management features \\\\n- **[DAO-2]** Support view methods for the list of proposals \\\\n\\\\nJS Backend features:\\\\n- **[JS-1]** Fetch and process data from DAO contract\\\\n- **[JS-2]** Cache data for the BOS UI\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Why should the committee choose this project?\\\\n\\\\nThis project is in line with the Committee\\\\\\'s priorities and our team has a proven background of delivering solutions in NEAR with similar architecture.\\\\n\\\\n### Will this solution be open source? What licensing are you releasing under?\\\\n\\\\nYes, MIT licensing.\\\\n\\\\n## Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\nThe whole project will take three months with monthly milestones\\\\n- Basic features (**BOS-2,BOS-3.1,BOS-3.2**)\\\\n- DAO management features (**BOS-3.3, BOS-3.4**)\\\\n- Browsing and voting (**BOS-4, BOS-5**)\\\\n \\\\n## Metrics\\\\n\\\\n### How will we measure success \\\\nDelivery of end-to-end journeys described in the Goals/Milestone section. We don\\\\u{2019}t have business metrics - only technical definitions of done which include code being available on GitHub under the MIT license.\\\\n\\\\n## Competitor Comparison\\\\n\\\\nPresented functionality is available in Astra++.  We outline several issues which were part of the motivation for the current proposal: \\\\n- Lack of ownership and absence of long-term vision-strategy for the products. The outcome is that the product becomes a pile of features (like a pizza - similar to what we have in \\\\u{201c}pizza coding\\\\u{201d} when developers just pile their code on top of the previous developers without having a single owner and without understanding of the approach that was taken by the previous developer).\\\\n- Dependency on closed-sourced indexers. Core contracts lacking view methods and data about DAOs is retrieved through an indexer developed by a 3-d party which is a closed source. Indexers in general are very unreliable and are the source of errors. For example, even a mature and well-recognized NEAR indexer built by Pagoda contains data errors which we found during our work - indexers are complicated in NEAR in general and wherever there is a complicated component there is room for an error. Moreover, architecture with indexers hinders scalability drastically, especially closed-sourced indexers.\\\\n- Lack of UX design - the product looks like a product for developers by developers which raises the entry barrier and results in the creation of DAOs only just to create a formal structure for funds funneling - the interface is not engaging people into the decentralized governance.\\\\n\\\\nWe offer to restructure DAO management tools in a completely open sourced fashion with usage of native view methods instead of indexers. \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n## Budget\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Total\\\\n$97,500 USD\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Breakdown\\\\n\\\\n- Engineering salaries - 81500 USD for 3 months of development. 1 month of full support is included.\\\\n- Management salaries - 15000 USD for 3 months\\\\n- Infra/tooling (servers lease, gas costs) - 1000USD\\\\nTotal - $97,500\\\\n\\\\n## Future plans\\\\nThis proposal addresses the first of the identified gaps in the current user experience in interacting with Sputnik-DAO contracts.\\\\n\\\\nOur future plans include the following:\\\\n\\\\n- Incorporate 3rd party applications to provide the functionality to handle general and decision-specific discussions in DAOs. This can be achieved by integrating with Social DB or with centralized applications (e.g. Discord, Zulip, Mattermost, Telegram). This integration requires additional research to provide a holistic approach that would be compatible with other applications that cover different functionality over the Sputnik-DAO contract\\\\n- Provide a reporting tool that would allow users to generate comprehensive, human-readable reports on funding, payments, and decision making. \\\\n\\\\nBoth of the points above will be addressed in individual proposals\\\\n\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "24a2788251373b64d58200665f12b00cfb2d6c9d2dc79b209d39cd0e433f5b3f", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "97500", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDT"}, "labels": ["Other"]}

{"data": {"infrastructure-committee.near": {"post": {"main": "{\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"md\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"We have just received a new *Infrastructure Committee* proposal.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n\\\\u{2014}\\\\u{2014}\\\\u{2014}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n**By**: @ftdgoodluck.near\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n**Title**: \\\\u{201c}[Spilka] BOS UI for DAO creation and configuration\\\\u{201c}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n**Summary**:\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nWe identified three principal gaps in current Sputnik-DAO UI capabilities\\\\\\\\n- DAO Management\\\\\\\\n- Discussions\\\\\\\\n- Reporting flow\\\\\\\\nIn this proposal, we consider implementing a BOS UI that focuses on the creation of DAO (wizard) and configuration (groups, legislative routines, thresholds). The goal is to lower the entry barrier for DAO enthusiasts who are not experienced developers.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThis proposal complements [RFP] NEAR MultiSig Treasury with a clear focus on DAO creation and management\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n\\\\u{2014}\\\\u{2014}\\\\u{2014}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nRead the full proposal and share your feedback on [DevHub](/devhub.near/widget/app?page=proposal&id=0)\\\\\\\"}"}, "index": {"post": "{\\\\\\\"key\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"main\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\":{\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"md\\\\\\\"}}"}}}}

The goal is to lower the entry barrier for DAO enthusiasts who are not experienced developers.\\\\n\\\\nThis proposal complements [RFP] NEAR MultiSig Treasury with a clear focus on DAO creation and management", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "REVIEW", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "editor_id": "ftdgoodluck.near", "timestamp": "1718731862642870232", "linked_rfp": null, "supervisor": null, "description": "## Organization\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\u{2019}s contact information\\\\nAlex Botezatu - Team Lead\\\\nEmail: botezatualex@gmail.com\\\\nTelegram: @botezatu\\\\nMobile: +380673753025\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the whole team\\\\n8 people.\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the engineering team\\\\n6 people - Product, Senior protocol engineer, 2 front-end engineers,UI/UX designer, QA engineer.\\\\n\\\\n### Team location\\\\nUkraine, Portugal.\\\\n\\\\n### Team background and bios\\\\n**Dan Polyakov, Product Lead**\\\\nHas been leading Product design teams for numerous crypto and fintech projects.\\\\nBitfury, KPMG, Golden Gate, NDC.\\\\n**Alex Botezatu, Ops Lead**\\\\nMore than 10 years of experience in building and managing R&D teams in web3.\\\\nBitfury, Aurora, NDC.\\\\n**Artur-Yurii Korchynskyi, Tech Lead**\\\\nInterchain Infrastructure Protocol: Programmable Layer 0 \\\\u{2022} ZK-Rollup \\\\u{2022} Advanced Liquidity Routing.\\\\n**Gleb Palienko, Project Manager**\\\\nHas been leading teams in web3 with project/product management and business development.\\\\nBitfury, P2P Validator, Boosty labs, Calimero.\\\\n**Andrii Saichuk, Front-End Engineer**\\\\nProficient Full Stack Web3 with over 10 years of experience in designing, developing, and maintaining complex web applications. Specializing in React.js for front-end development and proficient in NEAR. Owner of ZomLand and other Web3 dApps. Worked on NDC and contributed to open-source apps\\\\n**Andrii Furmanets, Front-End Engineer**\\\\nSpecialized in creating and deploying fintech and web3 applications. Recent work was focused on the NEAR blockchain and the Blockchain Operating System (BOS), where he has developed secure, scalable, and user-friendly decentralized applications.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Any affiliations with other NEAR ecosystem partners?\\\\nPart of the team (Dan, Alex B, Artur, Andrii S, Andrii F) worked on developing applications under the umbrella of NDC.\\\\nGleb worked in Calimero.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n## Professional Experience\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Examples of relevant experience with NEAR blockchain\\\\nDeveloped a voting solution for the stake-weighted voting. Developed applications for proposals and reports on funded initiatives on BOS.\\\\n\\\\n### Non-technical capabilities\\\\nAll non-engineer members of the group have been crypto native people since 2016.\\\\n\\\\nDan with his experience brings his ability to dive into the roots of every problem in Web3 resulting in the product vision and development lifecycle management.\\\\nAlex brings his management skills and ability to create, maintain, and manage highly qualified teams in the Web3 space.\\\\nGleb brings an outstanding combination of product/project management and business development skills that become the essence of the long-term strategy.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### In-House Resources\\\\n\\\\n- **Design, UX/UI** - we have an In-House UX/UI designer.\\\\n\\\\n- **Project management** - we have In-House project management capabilities.\\\\n\\\\n- **Customer support** - T3 engineering support. The management team can route support requests.\\\\n\\\\n- **BD / Marketing** - BD listed in non-technical capabilities.\\\\n\\\\n### Portfolio of relevant work\\\\n- https://github.com/near-ndc/voting-v2  - voting solution.\\\\n- https://github.com/near-ndc/ndc-widgets - BOS application for reports and proposals.\\\\n- https://github.com/ggxchain - Interchain infrastructure protocol.\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\n\\\\n### The primary approach and solution of the proposal.\\\\n\\\\n#### Project management approach\\\\n\\\\nWe utilize vertical slicing. Vertical slicing in agile breakdown refers to the practice of dividing work into thin, end-to-end slices that cut through all layers of the system to deliver a complete, functional piece of user value. Each vertical slice represents a small, independent feature or a user story that can be implemented, tested, and delivered to users.\\\\nHere are the key points about vertical slicing:\\\\n- Each vertical slice encompasses all necessary components (e.g., user interface, business logic, database interactions) to deliver a fully functional feature.\\\\n- The primary goal is to deliver tangible user value with each increment. This approach ensures that every slice results in a usable piece of software.\\\\n- Vertical slicing aligns with agile principles of incremental and iterative development, enabling us to deliver small, manageable pieces of functionality frequently.\\\\n- Vertical slicing encourages collaboration among team members with different expertise (e.g., frontend, backend, QA) to ensure that each slice is fully functional and integrated.\\\\n- By delivering complete features frequently, we can gather user feedback early and often, allowing for quicker adjustments and improvements.\\\\n- Since each vertical slice is a self-contained feature, integration issues are minimized compared to horizontal slicing, where different components must be integrated later.\\\\n\\\\nWe utilize an Agile approach with standard ceremonies (stand-up, grooming, refinement, review, retro). We will have 2-weeks sprints and we welcome Committee representatives to participate in our backlog management routines or review if needed. We aim to deliver tangible value each sprint and a practical piece of the end-to-end journey for each milestone.\\\\n\\\\nWe use Figma for the design. Reference for the style that will be used can be found [here](https://www.figma.com/design/Gaa51AGWBRTyKXF6TE2sjY/Astra%2B%2B-(Mobile)?node-id=0-1&t=CJlkI50FetgIrHtV-0).\\\\n\\\\n#### Solution overview\\\\nThe solution has four architectural components:\\\\n- Stable Sputnik DAO contract\\\\n- DAO contract created through the Sputnik DAO contract (%dao_name%.sputnik\\\\u{2026})\\\\n- BOS UI\\\\n- Open-source js backend\\\\n\\\\nBOS UI features:\\\\n- **[BOS-1]** Mobile first with adaptive design for the desktop\\\\n- **[BOS-2]** Wizard to create/disable DAO (new UX and implementation). Default user flow will create a DAO with 2 pre-set groups - Council and Members.\\\\n- **[BOS-3]** UI to define legislative proposal routines. \\\\n  - **[BOS-3.1]** Add/delete member to the group\\\\n  - **[BOS-3.2]** Add/delete group\\\\n  - **[BOS-3.3]** Add/delete funding threshold (e.g. if we have 10000, 50000, 10000 we can configure different quorum requirements for intervals 0-10000, 10000-50000, 50000-100000). A quorum requirement can be set for each group and using \\\\u{201c}AND\\\\u{201d} or \\\\u{201c}OR\\\\u{201d} logical operations e.g. need 60% councils AND 50% members.\\\\n  - **[BOS-3.4]** Add quorum requirement per group/funding threshold\\\\n- **[BOS-4]** UI to browse through legislative proposals with full data available on who voted how on each proposal\\\\n- **[BOS-5]** UI to vote on proposals\\\\n\\\\nDAO contract features:\\\\n- **[DAO-1]** Support data structures for DAO management features \\\\n- **[DAO-2]** Support view methods for the list of proposals \\\\n\\\\nJS Backend features:\\\\n- **[JS-1]** Fetch and process data from DAO contract\\\\n- **[JS-2]** Cache data for the BOS UI\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Why should the committee choose this project?\\\\n\\\\nThis project is in line with the Committee\\\\\\'s priorities and our team has a proven background of delivering solutions in NEAR with similar architecture.\\\\n\\\\n### Will this solution be open source? What licensing are you releasing under?\\\\n\\\\nYes, MIT licensing.\\\\n\\\\n## Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\nThe whole project will take three months with monthly milestones\\\\n- Basic features (**BOS-2,BOS-3.1,BOS-3.2**)\\\\n- DAO management features (**BOS-3.3, BOS-3.4**)\\\\n- Browsing and voting (**BOS-4, BOS-5**)\\\\n \\\\n## Metrics\\\\n\\\\n### How will we measure success \\\\nDelivery of end-to-end journeys described in the Goals/Milestone section. We don\\\\u{2019}t have business metrics - only technical definitions of done which include code being available on GitHub under the MIT license.\\\\n\\\\n## Competitor Comparison\\\\n\\\\nPresented functionality is available in Astra++.  We outline several issues which were part of the motivation for the current proposal: \\\\n- Lack of ownership and absence of long-term vision-strategy for the products. The outcome is that the product becomes a pile of features (like a pizza - similar to what we have in \\\\u{201c}pizza coding\\\\u{201d} when developers just pile their code on top of the previous developers without having a single owner and without understanding of the approach that was taken by the previous developer).\\\\n- Dependency on closed-sourced indexers. Core contracts lacking view methods and data about DAOs is retrieved through an indexer developed by a 3-d party which is a closed source. Indexers in general are very unreliable and are the source of errors. For example, even a mature and well-recognized NEAR indexer built by Pagoda contains data errors which we found during our work - indexers are complicated in NEAR in general and wherever there is a complicated component there is room for an error. Moreover, architecture with indexers hinders scalability drastically, especially closed-sourced indexers.\\\\n- Lack of UX design - the product looks like a product for developers by developers which raises the entry barrier and results in the creation of DAOs only just to create a formal structure for funds funneling - the interface is not engaging people into the decentralized governance.\\\\n\\\\nWe offer to restructure DAO management tools in a completely open sourced fashion with usage of native view methods instead of indexers. \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n## Budget\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Total\\\\n$97,500 USD\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Breakdown\\\\n\\\\n- Engineering salaries - 81500 USD for 3 months of development. 1 month of full support is included.\\\\n- Management salaries - 15000 USD for 3 months\\\\n- Infra/tooling (servers lease, gas costs) - 1000USD\\\\nTotal - $97,500\\\\n\\\\n## Future plans\\\\nThis proposal addresses the first of the identified gaps in the current user experience in interacting with Sputnik-DAO contracts.\\\\n\\\\nOur future plans include the following:\\\\n\\\\n- Incorporate 3rd party applications to provide the functionality to handle general and decision-specific discussions in DAOs. This can be achieved by integrating with Social DB or with centralized applications (e.g. Discord, Zulip, Mattermost, Telegram). This integration requires additional research to provide a holistic approach that would be compatible with other applications that cover different functionality over the Sputnik-DAO contract\\\\n- Provide a reporting tool that would allow users to generate comprehensive, human-readable reports on funding, payments, and decision making. \\\\n\\\\nBoth of the points above will be addressed in individual proposals\\\\n\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "24a2788251373b64d58200665f12b00cfb2d6c9d2dc79b209d39cd0e433f5b3f", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "97500", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDT"}, "author_id": "ftdgoodluck.near", "snapshot_history": [], "social_db_post_block_height": "0"}}

[Here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TVvPXPJhZfaFwfA2UMW6c3pO2kis45SJ1Np1XOkkhnA/edit?usp=sharing) is a standard template you can use as a starting point. Marketing materials, presentations, and images can be attached as needed.\\\\n\\\\n[Here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UZRfOE1JAOhsnSmp-RmL2hY7KPJbpBImKZVvPV4YJmA/edit?usp=sharing) is a Markup template.\\\\n\\\\n#### Dates\\\\n\\\\nThe deadline for proposal submission is [date].\\\\n\\\\n### Selection Process\\\\n\\\\nAfter reviewing the proposals, the committee will vote on the best one. Generally, this process takes two working weeks to complete and will be discussed and voted on at the regular bi-weekly meeting.\\\\n\\\\n#### Dates\\\\n\\\\nThe estimate for voting complete is [date].\\\\n\\\\n### Funding Process\\\\n\\\\nThe Infrastructure Committee governs funding with assistance from the NEAR Foundation. If selected, your proposal enters the funding pipeline. You are required to;\\\\n\\\\n* Complete the KYC/B process conducted by the NEAR Foundation, including verification by the IDVerify.\\\\n* Sign a legal agreement regarding the work as outlined in the proposal conducted by the NEAR Foundation.\\\\n* Submit an invoice to NEAR Foundation Finance outlining how you want funds disbursed, to what wallets or banks, and in the agreed-upon amounts.\\\\n* Completing a test transaction to verify target wallets (when requesting funds in cryptocurrency).\\\\n\\\\n#### Dates\\\\n\\\\nIf the proposal does not require clarifications in the budget, work approach, legal agreement, or invoicing terms, the funding process is generally completed in one working week.\\\\n\\\\n## Communication\\\\n\\\\nPlease direct all communications to the thread where the RFP started beneath the submitted proposal. Please direct confidential or sensitive communications to the Telegram group set up between the committee and the organization/entity/team. If you don\\\\u{2019}t have a private Telegram group between your team and the Infrastructure Committee, please request one in this thread.\\\\n", "rfp_body_version": "V0", "submission_deadline": "1727740800000000000"}, "labels": ["Other"]}

Generally, this process takes two working weeks to complete and will be discussed and voted on at the regular bi-weekly meeting.\\\\n\\\\n#### Dates\\\\n\\\\nThe estimate for voting complete is [date].\\\\n\\\\n### Funding Process\\\\n\\\\nThe Infrastructure Committee governs funding with assistance from the NEAR Foundation. If selected, your proposal enters the funding pipeline. You are required to;\\\\n\\\\n* Complete the KYC/B process conducted by the NEAR Foundation, including verification by the IDVerify.\\\\n* Sign a legal agreement regarding the work as outlined in the proposal conducted by the NEAR Foundation.\\\\n* Submit an invoice to NEAR Foundation Finance outlining how you want funds disbursed, to what wallets or banks, and in the agreed-upon amounts.\\\\n* Completing a test transaction to verify target wallets (when requesting funds in cryptocurrency).\\\\n\\\\n#### Dates\\\\n\\\\nIf the proposal does not require clarifications in the budget, work approach, legal agreement, or invoicing terms, the funding process is generally completed in one working week.\\\\n\\\\n## Communication\\\\n\\\\nPlease direct all communications to the thread where the RFP started beneath the submitted proposal. Please direct confidential or sensitive communications to the Telegram group set up between the committee and the organization/entity/team. If you don\\\\u{2019}t have a private Telegram group between your team and the Infrastructure Committee, please request one in this thread.\\\\n", "block_height": "121485225", "linked_proposals": [], "rfp_body_version": "V0", "submission_deadline": "1727740800000000000"}, "author_id": "trechriron71.near", "snapshot_history": [], "social_db_post_block_height": "0"}}
